title: ARMap
content:
ARMap 

 This is a helper class for manipulating an ARMap (AddressRangeMap), a
 non-overlapping interval map. We provide both F#- and C#-style APIs.
 
ARMap.empty 
empty 
ARMap.isEmpty 
isEmpty 
ARMap.add 
add 
ARMap.addRange 
addRange 
ARMap.replace 
replace 
ARMap.remove 
remove 
ARMap.removeAddr 
removeAddr 
ARMap.containsAddr 
containsAddr 
ARMap.containsRange 
containsRange 
ARMap.find 
find 
ARMap.findByAddr 
findByAddr 
ARMap.tryFindKey 
tryFindKey 
ARMap.tryFind 
tryFind 
ARMap.tryFindByAddr 
tryFindByAddr 
ARMap.count 
count 
ARMap.iter 
iter 
ARMap.fold 
fold 
ARMap.getOverlaps 
getOverlaps

title: ARMap.empty
content:
ARMap.empty 
empty 

 Return an empty map.

title: ARMap.isEmpty
content:
ARMap.isEmpty 
isEmpty 

   Check if the give interval map is empty.

title: ARMap.add
content:
ARMap.add 
add 

   Add a mapping from an interval to the value in the interval tree.

title: ARMap.addRange
content:
ARMap.addRange 
addRange 

   This function is the same as add except that this one takes in two
   separate parameters for min and max, instead of taking in an AddrRange
   as input.

title: ARMap.replace
content:
ARMap.replace 
replace 

   This function is the same as add except that it will overwrite the
   existing range if it exactly matches with the given range. If ranges
   overlap, this function will still raise RangeOverlapException.

title: ARMap.remove
content:
ARMap.remove 
remove 

   Remove a mapping that matches exactly with the given range. To remove a
   mapping that covers the given address, use removeAddr.

title: ARMap.removeAddr
content:
ARMap.removeAddr 
removeAddr 

   Remove a mapping that matches with the given address. Unlike remove,
   this function will remove an interval that includes the given address.

title: ARMap.containsAddr
content:
ARMap.containsAddr 
containsAddr 

   Check whether a given Addr exists in any of the ranges in the map.

title: ARMap.containsRange
content:
ARMap.containsRange 
containsRange 

   Check whether the exact range exists in the interval map.

title: ARMap.find
content:
ARMap.find 
find 

   Find the mapping that exactly matches with the given range.

title: ARMap.findByAddr
content:
ARMap.findByAddr 
findByAddr 

   Find the mapping that matches with the given range. Unlike find, this
   function can return a range that covers the given address.

title: ARMap.tryFindKey
content:
ARMap.tryFindKey 
tryFindKey 

   Find an interval stored in the interval tree map, which includes the
   given address.

title: ARMap.tryFind
content:
ARMap.tryFind 
tryFind 

   Same as find, except that this returns an option-wrapped type.

title: ARMap.tryFindByAddr
content:
ARMap.tryFindByAddr 
tryFindByAddr 

   Same as findByAddr, except that this returns an option-wrapped type.

title: ARMap.count
content:
ARMap.count 
count 

   Return the number of bindings in the interval map.

title: ARMap.iter
content:
ARMap.iter 
iter 

   Iterate over the tree.

title: ARMap.fold
content:
ARMap.fold 
fold 

   Fold over the tree.

title: ARMap.getOverlaps
content:
ARMap.getOverlaps 
getOverlaps 

   Return a sequence of overlapping mappings of the given interval.

ByteArray 

 It is sometimes convenient to consider a binary chunk as a byte array. This
 module provides several useful functions to deal with byte arrays.

ByteArray.toUInt32Arr 
toUInt32Arr

matchSpan

title: ARMap<'V>
content:
ARMap<'V> 

 This is a non-overlapping interval map that we call "Address Range Map"
 (ARMap). This map internally forms a red-black tree, which follows the
 implementation of the paper written by Kimball Germane and Matthew Might:
 "Deletion: The Curse of the Red-Black Tree", Journal of Functional
 Programming, vol. 24, no. 4, 2014.

AddrRange

 that are greater or equal to the min value (inclusive) and are less than or

title: ArchOperationMode
content:
ArchOperationMode 

 Some ISA, such as ARM, have their own operation mode, which can vary at
 runtime. For example, ARM architecture can switch between Thumb and ARM

 parsing/lifting machine instructions.

title: BitVector
content:
BitVector 

 BitVector is the fundamental data type for binary code, which is essentially
 a bit vector. We want the size of a bit vector to be less than or equal to
 64 bits because bigint operation is slow, and most arithmetics on modern
 architectures are in 64 bits any ways. For example, SIMD operations can also
 be divided into a set of 64-bit operations.

 N.B. Num becomes zero when the Length becomes greater than 64. We
 intentionally do not sync Num and BigNum.

title: ConsoleCachedPrinter
content:
ConsoleCachedPrinter 

 ConsoleCachedPrinter prints out non-colored strings only when the Flush
 method is called. All the colored strings will be normalized to plain
 strings. It will simply stack up all the output candidates before Flush is
 called. This is useful for performance-critical applications.
 
ConsoleCachedPrinter.( .ctor ) 
( .ctor )

title: ConsoleNullPrinter
content:
ConsoleNullPrinter 

 ConsoleCachedPrinter does not print anything. This is the same as
 redirecting outputs to /dev/null.
 
ConsoleNullPrinter.( .ctor ) 
( .ctor )

title: ConsolePrinter
content:
ConsolePrinter 

 ConsolePrinter simply prints out strings to console whenever a print method
 is called. This printer does not perform any caching, so it immediately
 flushes out all the strings to console.
 
ConsolePrinter.( .ctor ) 
( .ctor )

title: Printer.PrintLineIfPrevLineWasNotEmpty
content:
Printer.PrintLineIfPrevLineWasNotEmpty 
PrintLineIfPrevLineWasNotEmpty 

 Print out a newline only if the previous output was not empty (i.e., a
 line with only a newline). In other words, this function will not output
 anything if the previous output was an empty line. This is to make sure we
 output only one single empty line in some situations.

title: E
content:
E 

 IR Expressions.
 NOTE: You MUST create Expr/Stmt through the AST module. *NEVER* directly
 construct Expr nor Stmt.
 
E.Num 
Num 
E.Var 
Var

Nil 
E.PCVar 
PCVar 
E.TempVar 
TempVar 
E.UnOp 
UnOp 
E.Name 
Name

FuncName 
E.BinOp

E.RelOp 
RelOp 
E.Load 
Load 
E.Ite 
Ite 
E.Cast 
Cast 
E.Extract 
Extract 
E.Undefined 
Undefined

title: E.Num
content:
E.Num 
Num 

 A number. For example, (0x42:I32) is a 32-bit number 0x42

title: E.Var
content:
E.Var 
Var 

 A variable that represents a register of a CPU. Var (t, r, n) indicates
 a variable of type (t) that has RegisterID r and name (n).
 For example, (EAX:I32) represents the EAX register (of type I32).
 Note that name (n) is additional information that doesn't be used
 internally.

title: E.Nil
content:
E.Nil 
Nil 

 Nil to represent cons cells. This should only be used with BinOpType.CONS.

title: E.PCVar
content:
E.PCVar 
PCVar 

 A variable that represents a Program Counter (PC) of a CPU.

title: E.TempVar
content:
E.TempVar 
TempVar 

 A temporary variable represents an internal (imaginary) register. Names
 of temporary variables should always be affixed by an underscore (_) and
 a number. This is to make sure that any temporary variable is unique in
 a CFG. For example, a temporary variable T can be represented as
 (T_2:I32), where 2 is a unique number assigned to the variable.

title: E.UnOp
content:
E.UnOp 
UnOp 

 Unary operation such as negation.

title: E.Name
content:
E.Name 
Name 

 Symbolic constant for labels.

title: E.FuncName
content:
E.FuncName 
FuncName 

 Name of uninterpreted function.

title: E.BinOp
content:
E.BinOp 
BinOp 

 Binary operation such as add, sub, etc. The second argument is a result
 type after applying BinOp.

title: E.RelOp
content:
E.RelOp 
RelOp 

 Relative operation such as eq, lt, etc.

title: E.Load
content:
E.Load 
Load 

 Memory loading such as LE:[T_1:I32]

title: E.Ite
content:
E.Ite 
Ite 

 If-then-else expression. The first expression is a condition, and the
 second and the third are true and false expression respectively.

title: E.Cast
content:
E.Cast 
Cast 

 Type casting expression. The first argument is a casting type, and the
 second argument is a result type.

title: E.Extract
content:
E.Extract 
Extract 

 Extraction expression. The first argument is target expression, and the
 second argument is the number of bits for extraction, and the third is
 the start position.

title: E.Undefined
content:
E.Undefined 
Undefined 

 Undefined expression. This is rarely used, and it is a fatal error when we
 encounter this expression while evaluating a program. Some CPU manuals
 explicitly say that a register value is undefined after a certain
 operation. We model such cases with this expression.

title: S
content:
S 

 IL Statements.
 NOTE: You MUST create Expr/Stmt through the AST module. *NEVER* directly
 construct Expr nor Stmt.
 
S.ISMark 
ISMark 
S.IEMark 
IEMark 
S.LMark 
LMark 
S.Put 
Put 
S.Store 
Store 
S.Jmp 
Jmp 
S.CJmp 
CJmp 
S.InterJmp 
InterJmp 
S.InterCJmp 
InterCJmp 
S.SideEffect 
SideEffect

title: S.ISMark
content:
S.ISMark 
ISMark 

 Metadata representing the start of a machine instruction. More
 specifically, it contains the length of the instruction. There must be a
 single IMark per a machine instruction.

title: S.IEMark
content:
S.IEMark 
IEMark 

 Metadata representing the end of a machine instruction. It contains the
 length of the current instruction.

title: S.LMark
content:
S.LMark 
LMark 

 Metadata representing a label (as in an assembly language). LMark is only
 valid within a machine instruction.

title: S.Put
content:
S.Put 
Put 

 This statement puts a value into a register. The first argument is a
 destination operand, and the second argument is a source operand. The
 destination operand should have either a Var or a TempVar.

 Example: [Put(T_1:I32, Load(LE, T_2:I32))]
 loads a 32-bit value from the address T2, and store the value to the
 temporary register T1.

title: S.Store
content:
S.Store 
Store 

 This statement stores a value into a memory. The first argument
 represents the endianness, the second argument is a destination operand,
 and the third argument is a value to store.

 Example: Store(LE, T_1:I32, T_2:I32)
 stores a 32-bit value T_2 into the address T_1

title: S.Jmp
content:
S.Jmp 
Jmp 

 This statement represents a jump (unconditional) to an LMark. The first
 argument specifies the target address.

title: S.CJmp
content:
S.CJmp 
CJmp 

 This statement represents a conditional jump to an LMark. The first
 argument specifies a jump condition. If the condition is true, jump to
 the address specified by the second argument. Otherwise, jump to the
 address specified by the third argument.

title: S.InterJmp
content:
S.InterJmp 
InterJmp 

 This is an unconditional jump instruction to another instruction. This is
 an inter-instruction jump unlike Jmp statement. The first argument is the
 jump target address.

title: S.InterCJmp
content:
S.InterCJmp 
InterCJmp 

 This is a conditional jump instruction to another instruction. The first
 argument specifies a jump condition. If the condition is true, change the
 program counter to jump to the address specified by the second argument.
 Otherwise, jump to the address specified by the third argument.

title: S.SideEffect
content:
S.SideEffect 
SideEffect 

 This represents an instruction with side effects such as a system call.

title: FileInfo.GetDynamicSymbols
content:
FileInfo.GetDynamicSymbols 
GetDynamicSymbols 

   Return a list of all the dynamic symbols from the binary. Dynamic
   symbols are the ones that are required to run the binary. The
   "excludeImported" argument indicates whether to exclude external symbols
   that are imported from other files. However, even if "excludeImported"
   is true, returned symbols may include a forwarding entry that redirects
   to another function in an external file (cf. SymbolKind.ForwardType).
   When "excludeImported" argument is not given, this function will simply
   return all possible dynamic symbols.

content:

GetExecutableSections 

   Get a sequence of executable sections including linkage table code
   sections such as PLT.

title: FileInfo.GetFunctionAddresses
content:
FileInfo.GetFunctionAddresses 
GetFunctionAddresses 

   Returns a sequence of local function addresses (excluding external
   functions) from a given FileInfo. If the argument is true, then this
   funciton utilizes exception information of the binary to infer function
   entries. Note that the inference process is not necessarily precise, so
   this is really just an experimental feature, and will be removed in the
   future.

title: FileInfo.GetFunctionAddresses
content:

   removed before releasing it.

title: FileInfo.IsExecutableAddr
content:
FileInfo.IsExecutableAddr 
IsExecutableAddr 

   Check if the given address is executable address for this binary. We say
   a given address is executable if the address is within an executable
   section.

title: FileInfo.IsInFileAddr
content:
FileInfo.IsInFileAddr 
IsInFileAddr 

   Check if the given address is valid and there is an actual mapping from
   the binary file to the corresponding memory. Unlike IsValidAddr, this
   function checks if we can decide the actual value of the given address
   from the binary. For example, a program header of an ELF file may
   contain 100 bytes in size, but when it is mapped to a segment in memory,
   the size of the segment can be larger than the size of the program
   header. This function checks if the given address is in the range of the
   segment that has a direct mapping to the file's program header.

title: FileInfo.IsInFileRange
content:
FileInfo.IsInFileRange 
IsInFileRange 

   Check if the given address range is valid and there exists a
   corresponding region in the actual binary file. This function returns
   true only if the whole range of the addressess are valid (for every
   address in the range, IsInFileAddr should return true).

title: FileInfo.IsLinkageTable
content:
FileInfo.IsLinkageTable 
IsLinkageTable 

   Return if a given address is an address of a linkage table entry.

title: FileInfo.IsValidAddr
content:
FileInfo.IsValidAddr 
IsValidAddr 

   Check if the given address is valid for this binary. We say a given
   address is valid for the binary if the address is within the range of
   statically computable segment ranges.

title: FileInfo.IsValidRange
content:
FileInfo.IsValidRange 
IsValidRange 

   Check if the given address range is valid. This function returns true
   only if the whole range of the addressess are valid (for every address
   in the range, IsValidAddr should return true).

title: ProgramHeader
content:
ProgramHeader 

 An executable or shared object file's program header table is an array of
 structures, each of which describes a segment or the other information a
 system needs to prepare for execution. An object file segment contains one
 or more sections. Program headers are meaningful only for executable and
 shared object files. A file specifies its own program header size with
 the ELF header's members.

title: ProgramHeader.PHFileSize

content:

 nothing in the binary file, but can be mapped in the segment at runtime.

title: ProgramHeaderType.PTDynamic
content:

PTDynamic 

 This segment contains dynamic linking information.

title: ProgramHeaderType.PTInterp
content:
ProgramHeaderType.PTInterp 
PTInterp 

 This segment contains the location and size of a null-terminated path name
 to invoke an interpreter. This segment type is meaningful only for
 executable files, but not for shared objects. This segment may not occur
 more than once in a file. If it is present, it must precede any loadable
 segment entry.

title: ProgramHeaderType.PTNote
content:
ProgramHeaderType.PTNote 
PTNote 

 This segment contains the location and size of auxiliary information.

title: ProgramHeaderType.PTShLib
content:
ProgramHeaderType.PTShLib 
PTShLib 

 This segment type is reserved but has unspecified semantics.

title: ProgramHeaderType.PTPhdr
content:
ProgramHeaderType.PTPhdr 
PTPhdr 

 This segment specifies the location and size of the program header table
 itself, It may occur only if the program header table is part of the
 memory image of the program. If it is present, it must precede any
 loadable segment entry.

title: ProgramHeaderType.PTTLS
content:

PTTLS

content:

title: ProgramHeaderType.PTGNUEHFrame
content:

title: ProgramHeaderType.PTGNUStack
content:
ProgramHeaderType.PTGNUStack 
PTGNUStack 

 This segment specifies the permissions on the segment containing the stack
 and is used to indicate weather the stack should be executable. The
 absence of this header indicates that the stack will be executable.

 made read-only after relocations have been processed.

content:

SymbolVisibility.STVDefault 
STVDefault 
SymbolVisibility.STVInternal 
STVInternal 
SymbolVisibility.STVHidden 
STVHidden

title: SymbolVisibility.STVDefault
content:
SymbolVisibility.STVDefault 
STVDefault 

 Use the visibility specified by the symbol's binding type (SymbolBind).

title: SymbolVisibility.STVInternal
content:
SymbolVisibility.STVInternal 
STVInternal 

 This visibility attribute is currently reserved.

title: SymbolVisibility.STVHidden
content:
SymbolVisibility.STVHidden 
STVHidden 

 A symbol defined in the current component is hidden if its name is not
 visible to other components. Such a symbol is necessarily protected. This
 attribute is used to control the external interface of a component. An
 object named by such a symbol may still be referenced from another
 component if its address is passed outside.

title: SymbolVisibility.STVProtected
content:
SymbolVisibility.STVProtected 
STVProtected 

 A symbol defined in the current component is protected if it is visible in
 other components but cannot be preempted. Any reference to such a symbol
 from within the defining component must be resolved to the definition in
 that component, even if there is a definition in another component that
 would interpose by the default rules.

title: BinHandle.Init
content:
BinHandle.Init 
Init 

   Initialize a BinHandle from an ISA and a binary file path, assuming
   that the archMode is NoMode. B2R2 will automatically detect the file
   format of the given binary file, but it will refer to the given ISA
   parameter either when the binary has multiple architectures, e.g., a fat
   binary on macOS, or when B2R2 cannot recognize the given file format. If
   the given binary file does not follow the known formats, then B2R2
   consider it as a raw binary with base address at 0.

title: BinHandle.Init

   constructor Init (isa, bytes), with a difference of using the specified
   base address when initializing the BinHandle.

   2-argument constructor Init (isa, fileName), with a difference of using
   the specified base address when initializing the BinHandle.

title: BinHandle.Init

   if autoDetect is true. Otherwise, it will consider the given binary
   sequence as a raw binary (just a series of machine instructions without
   specific file format).

title: LiftingOperators.( !! )
content:
LiftingOperators.( !! ) 
( !! ) 

 This is the special operator that we use for writing a lifter. There are
 several major operators we use including this one. This one simply appends a
 statement to the IRBuilder. We always put a IRBuilder variable immediately
 after each operator without any space to make it visually distinct. For
 example, for a builder variable "ir", we write a lifting logic as follows:
 !<ir insAddr insLen
 !!ir (t1 := v1 .+ v2)
 !!ir (t2 := t1 .* t1)
 !>ir insAddr insLen

title: Instruction.IsBranch

   Is this a branch instruction? A branch instruction includes any kinds of
   jump instructions, such as CALL/RET instructions, indirect/direct jump
   instructions, and conditional jump instructions.

title: Instruction.IsCJmpOnTrue
content: Instruction.IsCJmpOnTrue IsCJmpOnTrue Is this a conditional branch instruction, and it jumps to the branch target when the predicate is true? For example, this method returns true for JE instructions of Intel, but false for JNE instructions.

content:

title: Instruction.IsDirectBranch
content: Instruction.IsDirectBranch IsDirectBranch Is this a direct branch instruction? A direct branch instruction is a branch instruction with a concrete jump target, which is inscribed in its operand. For example, CALL ECX is not a direct branch instruction, but JMP +10 is.

title: Instruction.IsExit
content: Instruction.IsExit IsExit Does this instruction exits the program execution? For example, this function returns true for the HLT instruction of Intel. We also consider returning from kernel mode to user mode (e.g. SYSEXIT instruction of Intel) as an exit.

title: Instruction.IsIndirectBranch
content:

   Is this an indirect branch instruction? An indirect branch instruction
   is a branch instruction with a symbolic jump target. Thus, the jump
   target is only computed at runtime.

title: Parser.parse
content:
Parser.parse 
parse 

 Read in bytes and return a parsed instruction for ARMv8. This function
 returns ARM64Instruction, which is a specialized type for 64-bit ARM. If you
 want to handle instructions in a platform-agnostic manner, you'd better use
 the ARM64Parser class.

title: Condition.NE
content:
Condition.NE 
NE 

 Not equal/Not equal or unordered (Z == 0).

title: Condition.CS
content:
Condition.CS 
CS 

 Carry set/Greater than, equal, or unordered (C == 1).
 HS (unsigned higher or same) is a synonym for CS.

title: Condition.CC
content:
Condition.CC 
CC 

 Carry clear/Less than (C == 0).
 LO (unsigned lower) is a synonym for CC.

title: Condition.PL
content:
Condition.PL 
PL 

 Plus, positive or zero/Greater than, equal, or unordered (N == 0).

title: Condition.HI
content:
Condition.HI 
HI 

 Unsigned higher/Greater than, or unordered (C ==1 && Z == 0).

title: Condition.LS
content:
Condition.LS 
LS 

 Unsigned lower or same/Less than or equal (!(C ==1 && Z ==0)).

title: Condition.GE
content:
Condition.GE 
GE 

 Signed greater than or equal/Greater than or equal (N == V).

title: Condition.LT
content:
Condition.LT 
LT 

 Signed less than/Less than, or unordered (N! = V).

title: Condition.GT
content:
Condition.GT 
GT 

 Signed greater than Greater than (Z == 0 && N == V).

title: Condition.LE
content:
Condition.LE 
LE 

 Signed less than or equal/Less than, equal, or unordered
 (!(Z == 0 && N == V)).

title: Condition.NV
content:
Condition.NV 
NV 

 Always/Always (Any).
 The condition code NV exists only to provide a valid disassembly of
 the 0b1111 encoding, otherwise its behavior is identical to AL.

title: Register
content:
Register ARMv8 registers. Below is how we encode register as a 20-bit integer. 

   19 18 17 16 15        ...        00 (bit position)
   +----------+----------------------+
   | Kind     |  Register ID.        |
   +----------+----------------------+

   # Kind (19 - 16)
   - 0000 : General purpose registers.
   - 0001 : SIMD registers.
   - 0010 : VFP registers.
   - 0011 : Co-processor registers.
   - 0100 : Control flags.
   - 0101 : Control register.

title: Kind.PseudoRegister
content:
Kind.PseudoRegister 
PseudoRegister 

 PseudoRegisters are the ones that we create to ease handling AVX
 registers and operations. Each AVX register is divided into a series of
 64-bit pseudoregisters, and we name each pseudoregister using a suffix
 character from 'A' to 'H'. For example, XMM0A refers to the first 64-bit
 chunk of XMM0.

title: IntelInternalInstruction.PointerSize
content:
IntelInternalInstruction.PointerSize 
PointerSize 

 Size of the memory pointer in the instruction, i.e., how many bytes are
 required to represent a memory address. This field may hold a dummy value
 if there's no memory operand. This is mainly used for the lifting purpose
 along with the MainOperationSize.

title: IntelInternalInstruction.MainOperationSize
content:
IntelInternalInstruction.MainOperationSize 
MainOperationSize 

 Size of the main operation performed by the instruction. This field is
 mainly used by our lifter, and we suggest not to use this field for
 analyzing binaries because there is some ambiguity in deciding the
 operation size when the instruction semantics are complex. We use this
 only for the purpose of optimizing the lifting process.

 We define four different types of X86 operands:
 register, memory, direct address, and immediate.
 
Operand.OprReg 
OprReg 
Operand.OprMem 
OprMem 
Operand.OprDirAddr 
OprDirAddr 
Operand.OprImm 
OprImm 
Operand.Label 
Label

title: Operand.OprMem
content:
Operand.OprMem 
OprMem 

 OprMem represents a memory operand. The OperandSize here means the memory
 access size of the operand, i.e., how many bytes do we read/write here.

title: Operand.OprDirAddr
content:
Operand.OprDirAddr 
OprDirAddr 

 OprDirAddr is a direct branch target address.

title: Operand.OprImm
content:
Operand.OprImm 
OprImm 

 OprImm represents an immediate operand. The OperandSize here means the
 size of the encoded immediate value.

title: Operand.Label
content:
Operand.Label 
Label 

 Label is *not* encoded in the actual binary. This is only used when we
 assemble binaries.

title: Register
content:
Register Registers for x86 (and x86-64).

Internally, a Register is represented with an integer (we use only 22 bits). The most significant 10 bits (from 12th to 21th bits) represent the size of the register. The next 4 bits (from 8th to 11th bits) represent the register kind, and the reset of 8 bits are used to represent a register ID. There are currently 13 kinds of registers including GP, FPU, MMX, etc. 

 21 ... 13 12 11 10 09 08 07 06 05 04 03 02 01 00 (bit position)
 +------------+----------+----------------------+
 |  Size      | Kind     |  Register ID.        |
 +------------+----------+----------------------+

title: SzCond
content:
SzCond 

 Specific conditions for determining the size of operands.
 (See Table A-1, Appendix A.2.5 of Vol. 2D).
 
SzCond.D64 
D64 
SzCond.F64 
F64 
SzCond.Nor 
Nor

title: SzCond.D64
content:
SzCond.D64 
D64 

 (d64) When in 64-bit mode, instruction defaults to 64-bit operand size and
 cannot encode 32-bit operand size.

title: SzCond.F64
content:
SzCond.F64 
F64 

 (f64) The operand size is forced to a 64-bit operand size when in 64-bit
 mode (prefixes that change operand size, e.g., 66 prefix, are ignored for
 this instruction in 64-bit mode).

title: SzCond.Nor
content:
SzCond.Nor 
Nor 

 Normal conditions. This includes all other size conditions in Table A-1.

title: UnknownRegException
content:
UnknownRegException 

 This exception occurs when an UnknownReg is explicitly used. This exception
 should not happen in general.

title: ZeroingOrMerging

 behavior which either zeroes the masked elements or leave masked element
 unchanged.

title: Parser.parse
content:
Parser.parse 
parse 

 Read in bytes and return a parsed instruction for MIPS. This function
 returns MIPSInstruction, which is a specialized type for MIPS. If you want
 to handle instructions in a platform-agnostic manner, you'd better use the
 MIPS class.

title: Traversal.foldTopologically
content:
Traversal.foldTopologically 
foldTopologically 

 Topologically fold every vertex of the given graph. For every unreachable
 nodes, we accumulate vertices reachable from the node in a postorder
 fashion. The accumulated list becomes the reverse postordered vertices,
 which is essentially the same as a topologically sorted list of vertices.
 We then simply fold the accumulated list. The second parameter (root) is for
 providing root vertices in case there is no unreachable node, e.g., when
 there is a loop to the root node.

title: CFGEvents
content:
CFGEvents 

 List of CFGEvents. We divide events into three groups: (1) basic events, (2)
 callee-analysis events, and (3) per-function-analysis events. The basic
 events are essential ones for building regular CFGs. The callee-analysis
 events are to detect mutually recursive callee analysis events. The
 function-analysis events are to perform per-function analysis in order to
 recover high-level CFG information, such as no-return information, and
 indirect branch targets.
 
CFGEvents.BasicEvents 
BasicEvents 
CFGEvents.CalleeAnalysisEdges 
CalleeAnalysisEdges 
CFGEvents.FunctionAnalysisAddrs 
FunctionAnalysisAddrs

FakeEdge 

 FakeEdge is a tuple of (Callsite address, Call target address). This is to
 uniquely identify edges from a call instruction to a fake block. Note that

 callsites should be connected to an independent fake block. That's the
 reason why we use FakeEdge to distinguish them.

title: HistoricalFact

 during the recovery of an indirect branch. If a vertex has been promoted due
 to such an edge, and the edge has turned out to be invalid, then we should
 be able to revert the promotion.

title: IndirectJumpResolution
content:
IndirectJumpResolution 

 IndirectJumpResolution recovers jump targets of indirect jumps by inferring
 their jump tables. It first identifies jump table bases with constant
 propagation and recovers the entire table ranges by leveraging the
 structural properties of the binary.

title: PerFunctionAnalysis
content:
PerFunctionAnalysis 

 PerFunctionAnalysis implements a core CFG-recovery algorithm, which modifies
 a function-level CFG by analyzing the function. Though it works per
 function, It can modify other functions (thus, the entire CFGInfo). An
 analysis appends CFGEvents to modify function, but it can also modify the
 function directly.
 
PerFunctionAnalysis.( .ctor ) 
( .ctor )

title: TempInfo
content:
TempInfo 

 Temporary information obtained by parsing a block (bbl) of instructions,
 such as IR-level leaders and auxiliary information about an
 instruction-level basic block. This information is necessary to construct a
 (IR-level) CFG. Normally, a single instruction-level bbl represents a single
 IR-level basic block, but if there exist intra-instruction control flows, it
 can have multiple intra blocks.

title: TempInfo.HasExplicitTerminator
content:
TempInfo.HasExplicitTerminator 
HasExplicitTerminator 

 Flag indicating that IEMark statement follows a terminatinig statment,
 such as SideEffect. Although our IR optimizer will remove such IEMarks in
 most cases, there is one exception, though. If there is a SideEffect
 statement immediately followed by an IEMark, our optmizer will not remove
 the IEMark because we cannot assume that the SideEffect statement will
 advance the PC. In fact, the SideEffect statement does not necessarily
 know the size of the corresponding machine instruction. Thus, it is not
 natural to remove such IEMarks.

title: CFGEdgeKind.NoReturnFallThroughEdge
content:
CFGEdgeKind.NoReturnFallThroughEdge 
NoReturnFallThroughEdge 

 A fall-through after a no return call instruction. This edge will never be
 executed. We have this edge to include all "codes" compiler emitted. If we
 do not consider such "unreachable" codes from CFG building, we'll never
 see this edge in the result CFG.

title: CFGEdgeKind.ExceptionFallThroughEdge
content:
CFGEdgeKind.ExceptionFallThroughEdge 
ExceptionFallThroughEdge 

 A fall-through representing C++ exception flows. If there is a function
 call which causes raising exceptions, then this edge will be used.

title: CFGEdgeKind.ImplicitCallEdge
content:
CFGEdgeKind.ImplicitCallEdge 
ImplicitCallEdge 

 An implicit edge that is not explicitly visible from the current CALL
 instruction, but visible within the function. If there is a path in the
 callee that calls a function, then we create an implicit edge from a
 caller to any of the callees.

content:
CFGEdgeKind.UnknownEdge 
UnknownEdge 

 Unknown edge type. This should be an error case.

FakeVMap 

 This is a mapping from an edge to a dummy vertex (for external function

 associated with the same node (address) in order to compute dominance
 relationships without introducing incorrect paths or cycles. For
 convenience, we will always consider as a key "a return edge" from a fake
 vertex to a fall-through vertex.

title: InlinedAssemblyTypes
content:
InlinedAssemblyTypes 

 Sometimes, inlined assembly creates branches that jump into the middle of an
 instruction. For example, the following pattern is commonly found in Libc.

 41af15: 64 83 3c 25 18 00 00 00 00    cmpl  $0x0,%fs:0x18
 41af1e: 74 01                         je    41af21 <arena_get2.part.0+0x4a1>
 41af20: f0 48 ff 0d c0 57 0a 00       lock decq 0xa57c0(%rip)

 We call such the above code pattern as the "jump-after-lock" pattern.
 
InlinedAssemblyTypes.JumpAfterLock 
JumpAfterLock 
InlinedAssemblyTypes.NotInlinedAssembly 
NotInlinedAssembly

content:
InlinedAssemblyTypes.JumpAfterLock 
JumpAfterLock 

 The jump-after-lock pattern that spans multiple instruction addresses.

title: SparseConstantPropagation
content:
SparseConstantPropagation 

 The most basic constant propagation algorithm, which can track stack-based
 memory objects and GOT pointers. The reader is to enable reading data
 from external sections, e.g., rodata. If the reader is not given, we simply
 ignore such global data.
 
SparseConstantPropagation.( .ctor ) 
( .ctor )

title: StackPointerPropagation
content:
StackPointerPropagation 

 This is a variant of the SparseConstantPropagation, which only tracks
 the stack pointer used in a function. We initiate the stack pointer with a
 constant first, and check how it propagates within the function.
 StackPointerPropagation is generally much faster than
 SparseConstantPropagation due to its simplicity.
 
StackPointerPropagation.( .ctor ) 
( .ctor )

title: B2R2 API Document
content:
B2R2 API Document
===

B2R2 is a collection of useful algorithms, functions, and tools for **binary
analysis**, written purely in F# (in .NET lingo, it is purely managed code). For
further information about our project, visit our main repository:
https://github.com/B2R2-org/B2R2.
